parts.instructions: You are going to read a magazine article about an artist who paints flowers. For questions 8-14, choose the answer (A, B, C or D) which you think fits best according to the text.

passage.title: An eye for detail
passage.content:
Artist Carmen Rodriguez, sixty-five, says: But the gradual decaying process is also part of the fascination for her. With tulips, for example, 'you bring them in and put them in water, then leave them for perhaps a day and they each form themselves into different shapes. They open out and are fantastic. When you first put them in a vase, you think they are boring, but they change all the time with twists and turns.'

Carmen has always been interested in plants. 'I did botany at school and used to collect wild flowers from all around the countryside.' In the garden, she wasn't much interested in gardening then; 'I thought they were artificial looking. I only really liked ones were wild.' Nowadays, the garden owes its beauty to imported plants that originated in far-off lands, though they seem as much at home in her garden as they did in China or the Himalayas. She has a come-what-may attitude to the garden, rather like an affectionate aunt who is quite happy for children to play about undisciplined as long as they don't do any serious damage.

With two forthcoming exhibitions to prepare for, and a ready supply of subject material at her back door, finding time to paint is never a problem for Carmen recently. She now employs an extra gardener, but admits she need to paint, she knows that, to maintain her connection with her subject matter, you have to get your hands dirty.

Her busiest time of year is spring and early summer, when the tulips are out followed by the poppies. 'They all come out together, and you're so busy' she says. 'I take one flower out and paint it which is how I like to work, and then bring in another one and build up the painting that way. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish.'

Carmen prefers to focus on detailed studies of individual plants rather than on the garden as a whole, though she will occasionally paint a group of plants when positioned so as to provide the best viewing angle for the artist. She also inherited the gardener, Diego. 'In fact, I was really not interested in gardening.' We got on very well at first but would say, 'Oh, it's not worth it' to some of the things I wanted to put in, but when I said I wanted to plant them, he recognized what I had in mind.

people.name: Andrea Martinez - Newsreader
people.text: I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to get back there as often as I can. Last year I took the TGV, the high-speed train which crosses the border with Italy. I chose the route you take through some of the most amazing countryside. It never reaches what the weather is like, it is always enchanting. Out of the other window are some of the best black mountain scenery and vineyards in the Loire. There is sometimes a great view of the properties of the rich and famous. The millionaires' houses are always lively because there is an interesting mix of tourists and locals, but all different age groups, and admirers of the breathtaking scenery.

people.name: Roberto Silva - Explorer
people.text: I have been interested in trains for most of the years, but if I had to pick a favourite it would be the Orient Express. The one memorable journey I took was crossing northern Scotland. The one time I got there was when I was about in love with the train up in the Alps that crosses a desert or northern regions. London Waterloo was my starting point. I hadn't travelled by train. London was a big help when choosing the route.

people.name: Beatriz Cooper - Novelist
people.text: I always book my rail travel well in advance if I'm taking the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat in Egypt. It was on the train that my husband gave me a pink dress, which I thought was absolutely wonderful. Someone happened to mention that pink was good for the brain, and we fell about it our heads off. What I remember about the journey, however, is how lovely it was to journey down to the South of France and then by boat up the Nile to Luxor. It was, without a doubt, the perfect way to wind down after all the wedding preparations.

people.name: Martin Rodriguez - Journalist
people.text: We were working on a series of articles based on a 'round-the-world' trip and had to cross a desert to get to our final destination. We took the Desert Express. The timetable was unreliable to the limit - often given that we were told the train only ran when the driver thought there were enough passengers - that meant passengers were sometimes allowed to travel on the roof free. During the night, the train crossed some of the most beautiful landscapes I have never seen. It was like a painting that came to life when the moon appeared. There was a sudden change of what seemed like hundreds and hundreds of camel.

people.name: Jennifer Davis - Actress
people.text: I imagine most people's favourite impressions of trains and railways are formed when they are young children, but that's not my case. I was well past thirty when I was first interested in them. I wasn't until I was a teenager that travelling on trains began to dominate my life. I made a film which featured a railway as the storyline. Most of the filming took place on an old, disused stretch of the line which had been lovingly maintained by volunteers. I got very attached to that old train set, and when I went back last year, it was an amazing experience to find it unchanged, even the gas lights on the station platform.
